module.title: names
module.p: Names are expressions which identify and refer to a single entity – a specific person, place, song &c.
Names can be classified into two distinct grammatical types, based on the kinds of words they are made out of –

ul.li: proper nouns – single, intrinsically definite, words (with optional modifiers), e.g. Mairead Margaret, Glaschu Glasgow, Seumas Mòr Big James, Alba Nuadh Nova Scotia, Gairm [name of quarterly periodical]

name-descriptions – (capitalised) definite common noun expressions, e.g. An Caiptean The Captain, Bean Alasdair Alexander’s Wife, Am Ploc Plockton, Ceann Loch Chille Chiarain Campbeltown, Òran na Cloiche [song title]

module.p: Names can also be classified into a number of different semantic types, depending on the kind of entity named –

ul.li: anthroponyms – names of people eg. Mairead, An Caiptean
toponyms – names of places eg. Alba Nuadh, Am Ploc
‘grouponyms’ – names of groups of people – teams, organisations, institutions, companies, tribes &c eg. Misneachd [name of pressure group], An Comunn Gàidhealach The Highland Association
‘textonyms’ – names of scholarly and literary texts and other creative works eg. Gairm, Am Bìoball The Bible, Òran na Cloiche
glottonyms – names of languages and dialects eg. Laideann Latin, A’ Ghreugais Greek, Gàidhlig na h-Èireann Irish
‘eventonyms’ – names of events and historical eras eg. An Cogadh Mòr The Great War, Bliadhna Theàrlaich 1745-6, Linn an Umha The Bronze Age

module.p: Note that there are various typographical conventions used to make names distinct from surrounding written text – capitalisation, quotation marks, italics &c.
Note also that certain names are consistently lenited when they occur as genitive specifiers of a common noun, though this depends on the grammatical and semantic types of the name itself.
